Key Arguments: The legislation poses a greater threat to democracy and society than misinformation and disinformation themselves.
No one has a monopoly on the truth, making it impossible for the government to regulate misinformation effectively.
The legislation risks creating an Orwellian 'Ministry of Truth' scenario where the government dictates what is true.
Freedom of speech and the ability to contest ideas are essential to a functioning democracy.
Education, rather than regulation, is a better solution to combat misinformation and disinformation.
Notable Quotes: The implementation of the principle of 'government endorsed truth', detached from actual truth, is embodied in the dystopian society of the book 1984.
The only feasible cure for the problem is the freedom to disagree, to argue the counter-point, and persuade the electorate of the better way.
A government deciding on what is true and false is the greater threat to democracy, not the availability of contested competing ideas.
